awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mechanical Regulation of Cell Death
awd_abstract_narration:
For a person to be healthy, cells must be created and, at the right time, sometimes die.  There are many diseases that are caused by cells that don't die at the correct time.  The death of cells is changed by physical forces applied to and generated within tissues. However, relatively little is known about how the forces change the timing or speed of cell death. The interior molecules of a cell create and carry loads between cells. The goal of this research is to determine the specific role of the molecule actin, and the pathways that control actin, in the mechanical regulation of cell death. The work will identify small and large size molecules that can be manipulated by drugs to change how loads regulate cell death in many diseases, including tumors, heart disease, arthritis and osteoporosis. The project will support training of a doctoral student and six undergraduate researchers (REU) mentored between our campuses. As part of the program, these student researchers mentor girls from underserved middle-schools in a one-week program focused on gaining confidence through independent mini-research projects.

This project will advance the fundamental understanding of how forces are generated by single cells and within the context of multicellular tissues. It will elucidate how mechanical forces regulate cell death. The role of cell forces and actin dynamics in apoptosis will be studied at multiple scales; in clusters of cells, in individual cells, and at the molecular signaling scale. The overall approach is mechanics-based and combines experimental and computational models that inform each other to obtain accurate maps of the force distribution within cells and tissues. The work will identify how mechanical forces, the actin cytoskeleton, and relevant signaling pathways collectively regulate apoptosis. Quantitative knowledge of the mechanical signals that induce apoptosis and the mechanisms transmitting these signals is fundamental for understanding the underlying pathophysiology of various disease states that involve improper control of cell death.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Cell death is as critical as cell division for proper tissue growth and healing. When cell division is not balanced with programmed cell death, diseases such as cancer can result. Cell forces are very important for the proper functioning of tissues such as the heart valves, which are in constant motion. We know that physical stimuli (such as the stiffness and shape of surrounding tissue as well as stretching the tissue and the cells within the tissue) alters the balance between cell life and death. What is unclear is how these mechanical forces affect the cells, especially when the cells are interacting with each other. In this work, we found that in addition to single cell behavior, the group behavior of cells is important for deciding which cells divide and which die, and this appears to be important for heart valve cells. We used special engineered systems to study the cell-cell interactions, movement, division, and death in detail (Figure 1 left and middle). Computational models were used to estimate forces between cells that are impossible to directly measure (Figure 1 right). Further, cells banding together to generate higher forces (Figure 2 left) and signaling molecules (especially one named YAP) are critical in signaling cells to divide or undergo programmed cell death (Figure 2 middle and right). Finally, we found that how strongly cells pull in specific directions (along or across the cell direction) makes a difference in their life and death. To measure the directional properties of individual cells, we created a new method for probing cell mechanics that researchers will find useful not just for the heart valve, but also for studying other cells and tissues in health and disease such as stem cells and cancer cells.   

 

This work has substantial broader impacts including the training of three doctoral students. The PI ran a workshop for all biomedical graduate students on how to mentor undergraduate researchers which the PhD students funded on this grant participated in. These students mentored six female undergraduate students to become more independent researchers. The graduate students also mentored four senior project teams on work related to this grant (total of 16 undergraduates). For example, one group of four female engineering students designed a system to more efficiently make the specially shaped microscopic islands on which the cells are cultured. Another group designed a system to stretch cells in a custom dish. A team of three juniors completed an ?Interactive Qualifying Project? in which they studied how ethics of healthcare disparities it taught throughout the curriculum in technical courses and developed new modules, one of which is based on the research in this project. Another group of five juniors developed an interactive guide to aid senior capstone design groups in analyzing the ethical implications of their work, such as the senior design teams that worked on this project. The graduate researchers have each presented their work at national meetings, and undergraduate researchers have attended national meetings virtually (due to the pandemic) and some were able to attend in person this past year. One graduate student had an internship in a startup company funded by a supplement for this grant.

 

Scientifically, the findings from this project will impact our understanding of disease states such as tissue fibrosis and cancer and inform tissue engineering approaches. The methods developed will also be useful for characterizing the directional properties of tissues and cells without damaging them in the process. Three manuscripts, one review paper, and one book chapter have been published. Four additional papers are in process. Eight peer-reviewed conference proceedings have been accepted and presented at national conferences. The research was described in three offerings of our introductory biomedical engineering course and drew great interest from the students with lengthy discussion. The PI also presented this research to ~250 students each of the past three summers as part of our Virtual Immersion in Biomedical Engineering (VIBE) program that is offered free to BME students from around the country and the world.

 


Last Modified: 08/28/2023
Modified by: Kristen L Billiar

Images (1 of )

(middle) Quantification of stress fibers (red indicates higher cell forces). (right) Computers are used to estim
    Zachary Goldblatt
    Copyrighted
    Kristen L Billiar
    Analysis of group cell behavior
  • Figure 2. Cell death occurs when cells band together and become too dense. They generate high overall forces (left, red color), but the banding reduces signaling molecules important for survival (middle, purple color), and leads to cell death (right, red color).
    Mahvash Jebeli
    Copyrighted
    Kristen L Billiar
    Group motion, forces, growth, and death of cells
